items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Foothill High School PresentationWelcome to Foothill Continuation High School. The information in this summary is designed to provide you with an overview of the school’s direction and progress.The entire staff at Foothill invites your child to acquire the knowledge, life skills preparation and unique learning experiences necessary to ensure that they have acquired the background to establish life long learning. Foothill is a school for all students and strives to give all students the necessary skills and academic background to be successful in their current life and beyond. We offer a full array of courses and the support services necessary to prepare students to be successful beyond high school. Students at Foothill Continuation High School have the opportunity to work with social workers and a drug / alcohol counselor if needed. We provide these services, including a weekly health van, so that students can work on problems that may prevent them from learning and earning credits at Foothill Continuation High School. At Foothill Continuation High School one of our primary goals is to build relationships within our educational community. Toward that aim, we have partnered with local industry and social agencies to build and educational team that is committed to student achievement and educational growth.Foothill is dedicated to equity and success for all students and eagerly looks forward to providing the best learning opportunities possible.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Update on Summer School 2009At this time of the year, planning for summer school focuses on the enrollment of students, development of a master schedule, and the hiring of staff. Different this year in the planning process is the necessity to take into consideration the deteriorating state budget. The state budget crises has lowered the state’s “Supplemental Instruction” (state funding that pays for summer school) reimbursement rates such that ESUHSD can not offer the summer school based on student interest and demand but rather construct a summer school that  is cost neutral.  The end result is a 2009 summer school that will offer services to 7,500 students rather than the typical 10,000 plus students. Supplemental Instruction (SI) funding is divided into two categories “capped” and “uncapped” for grades 9-12.  The higher reimbursement rate of $2.92 per student hour funds students in courses preparing students for the CAHSEE.  These courses include CAHSEE Prep, English 1 (Repeat), English 2 (Repeat), Algebra I (Repeat), and geometry (Repeat).  All other courses fall under the “capped” reimbursement rate of $2.659.  Currently the state funds 5% of CBEDS through SI which translates to approximately 1,200 students.  Through leveraging efforts between the income produced from “uncapped” classes the district plans to offer classes to approximately 3,600 students.  Additional cost saving measures taken to reduce the total costs include site administration for supervision, a reduction in profession development days, the strategic placement of programs to reduce busing, and reduced number of courses.   FISCAL IMPACT:At current state SI Reimbursement Rates it is estimated summer school income will equal costs.                                                                                        FUNDING SOURCE:American Reinvestment and Recovery ActRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees continue with plans to provide summer school at a reduced level such that reimbursement rates equal costs.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Petition for Proposed Downtown College Prep – Alum Rock Charter SchoolOn March 5, 2009, the District received a charter petition from Across the Bridge Foundation, a non-profit corporation organized to provide education programs and services and to manage, operate, guide, direct and promote one or more California public charter schools.  The Petition from Across the Bridge Foundation proposes to establish Downtown College Prep – Alum Rock Charter School in the East Side Union High School / Alum Rock Community serving students in 6th through 12th grades.  The Petition proposes to gradually expand the curriculum at its Downtown College Prep – Alum Rock campus, Grades 6-12, to be completed by August / September 2016.The District held a public hearing on the Petition as required by law during the public session of the Board Meeting on April 9, 2009.At the public hearing, Julia Gonzalez Luna, New School Developer and Prospective Principal, presented information about the two other Downtown College Prep Charter School located in Alviso and downtown San Jose.  In addition several parents who reside in the East Side Union High School District addressed the Board to express their interest in sending their children to the proposed charter school.  No District teachers or other District employees addressed the Board at the hearing, or have otherwise expressed support for the proposed school.The District must now either grant or deny the charter petition.  The District may grant the charter “if it is satisfied that granting the charter is consistent with sound educational practice.”  The District may not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support or more of the following findings:	(1)	The charter school presents an unsound educational program for pupils to be 			enrolled in the charter school;	(2)	The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program 			set forth in the petition;	(3)	The petition does not contain the required number of signatures;	(4)	The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the required conditions set 			forth in section 47605(d); or	(5)	The petition does not contain reasonable comprehensive descriptions of the 15 			elements of a charter school set forth in Education Code Section 47605(b)If the Board makes one or more of these five findings, it must also adopt written factual findings that are specific to the issues raised in this particular Petition.The District’s administration team carefully reviewed and analyzed the Petition, and met with representatives from Across the Bridge Foundation in order to discuss their petition.  As set forth in the attached Proposed Findings, Administration recommends that the Downtown College Prep – Alum Rock Charter Petition be denied.FISCAL IMPACT:If approved there will be fiscal impact.  The anticipated fiscal impact is not subject to quantification at this time due to the varying uncertainties with state funding, actual charter operations and the extent to which the charter school draws upon non-reimbursable District services.FUNDING SOURCE:General FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees give careful consideration to this Petition and the concerns raised by the Administration.  If the Boards acts to deny the Petition, the Board should adopt the attached findings as support for the Board’s decision.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services, Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal CounselSUBJECT:Approval to Proceed with Solar and Energy Efficiency Project and Accept the California Solar Initiative Reservation Letter/Program Contract for Energy Incentives to Install Solar Projects The District currently has an operating budget shortfall and has been looking into ways to minimize the impact in order to save jobs and school programs.  Investing in energy efficiency improvements can provide immediate budget relief, local jobs, environmental benefits and educational opportunities without using bond funding.The District has been notified that they have been approved to receive incentives to design and build Solar Projects at our Schools.  By participating in this program, we will receive incentives up to $0.32/kWh for up to 6.5 MW of generating capacity.  This project will be phased in over a period of time and will only use funds available in the District's School Facilities Fund #35, which funds can only be used for capital projects.  Any expansion or use of other funding resources will require additional Board authorization.One significant benefit of these projects is the generation of renewable energy to supply 51% of the District's current electric use.  Not only is this the “right thing” to do for our environment, these projects will provide an estimated first year budget relief of approximately $2.1 million in the first calendar year.  Future energy cost savings will increase as energy rates continue to rise.FISCAL IMPACT: Reduced Energy Costs, Amount to be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE: School Facilities Fund #35RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to proceed with solar and energy efficiency projects and accept the California Solar Initiative Reservation Letter/Program Contract for energy incentives to install solar projects (Photovoltaic) at District Schools.  It is further recommended that the Board authorize the Associate Superintendent, Administration and Business Services to negotiate and execute a Solar Services Agreement and to fund the project with District funds and financing without using Bond Funding.

items.item_details: Senate Constitution Amendment 6 (Simitian), which reduces the two-thirds vote requirement for local parcel taxes, will be acted on by the California State Legislature.  Passage of Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian) will empower local voters to invest in their schools based on the needs of their communities by requiring a tough, but fair 55 percent vote to pass local parcel taxes, while protecting taxpayers and homeowners with accountability provisions that will ensure that funds generated from parcel taxes are not wasted or mismanaged.  Revenue from parcel taxes can be spent according to local priorities and are not subject to State control.	The Board is asked to urge the California State Legislature to support and adopt Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian).FISCAL IMPACT:        NoneFUNDING SOURCE:   NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2008/2009-36 which strongly urges the California State Legislature to support and adopt Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian).EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTofSanta Clara County, State of CaliforniaRESOLUTION #2008/2009-36Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian)WHEREAS, Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian), which reduces the two-thirds vote requirement on parcel taxes, will be acted on by the California State Legislature; andWHEREAS, reductions in the State General Fund revenue have led to reduced school funding; andWHEREAS, State General Fund revenue is unstable and erratic, which results in unpredictable funding levels for school districts and county offices of education; andWHEREAS, parcel tax revenue can provide a stable, predictable source of school revenue; andWHEREAS, passage of Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian) will empower local voters to invest in their schools based on the needs of their communities by requiring a tough, but fair 55 percent vote to pass local parcel taxes, while protecting taxpayers and homeowners with accountability provisions that will ensure that funds generated from parcel taxes are not wasted or mismanaged; andWHEREAS, revenue from parcel taxes can be spent according to local priorities and are not subject to State control; andWHEREAS, the two-thirds vote requirements results in minority rule by requiring two “yes” votes to cancel out one no vote; andWHEREAS, passage of Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian) will allow local voters to decide to make investments in their neighborhood schools in addition to State funding; andNOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District strongly urges the California State Legislature to support and adopt Senate Constitutional Amendment 6 (Simitian).PASSED AND ADOPTED this 4th day of June 2009 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.AYES: 	________NOES: 	________ABSENT:	________ABSTENTIONS: 	________I certify that the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on June 4, 2009._________________________Frank Biehl, ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Adopt Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Expelled Plan for YouthAs mandated by Education Code 48926, each county superintendent of schools in counties that operate community schools pursuant to Section 1980, in conjunction with superintendents of the school districts within the county, shall develop a plan for providing education services to all expelled pupils that county.  The plans shall be adopted by the governing board of each school district within the county and by the county board of education.The plan shall enumerate existing education alternatives for expelled pupils, identify gaps in educational services to expelled pupils, and strategies for filling those service gaps.  The plan shall also identify alternative placements for pupils who are expelled and placed in district community day school programs, but who fail to meet the terms of the conditions of their rehabilitation plan or who pose a danger to other district pupils, as determined by the governing board.Each county superintendent of schools, in conjunction with the superintendents of the school districts, shall submit to the Superintendent of Public Instruction the county plan for providing educational services to all expelled pupils in the county no later than June 30, 2009, and shall submit a triennial update to the plan to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, including the outcome data pursuant to Section 48916.1, on June 30th thereafter.Per Education Code 48916.1, at the time an expulsion of a pupil is order, the governing board of the school district shall ensure that an educational program is provided to the pupil who is subject to the expulsion order for the period of the expulsion, but only to the extent funds are appropriated for this purpose in the annual budget Act or other legislation, or both.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Expelled Plan for Youth.

At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.
